an2.42:1.3.pli: Uttānā ca parisā gambhīrā ca parisā.
an2.42:1.3.eng: A shallow assembly and a deep assembly.

an2.42:1.4.eng: And what is a shallow assembly?

an2.42:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū uddhatā honti unnaḷā capalā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā muṭṭhassatī asampajānā asamāhitā vibbhantacittā pākatindriyā.
an2.42:1.5.eng: An assembly where the mendicants are restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.

an2.42:1.6.eng: This is called a shallow assembly.

an2.42:2.1.eng: And what is a deep assembly?

an2.42:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū anuddhatā honti anunnaḷā acapalā amukharā avikiṇṇavācā upaṭṭhitassatī sampajānā samāhitā ekaggacittā saṃvutindriyā.
an2.42:2.2.eng: An assembly where the mendicants are not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, or loose-tongued, but have established mindfulness, situational awareness, immersion, unified minds, and restrained faculties.

an2.42:2.3.eng: This is called a deep assembly.

an2.42:2.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ gambhīrā parisā”ti.
an2.42:2.5.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the deep assembly.”

an2.43:1.3.pli: Vaggā ca parisā samaggā ca parisā.
an2.43:1.3.eng: A divided assembly and a harmonious assembly.

an2.43:1.4.eng: And what is a divided assembly?

an2.43:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti.
an2.43:1.5.eng: An assembly where the mendicants fight, quarrel, and dispute, continually wounding each other with barbed words.

an2.43:1.6.eng: This is called a divided assembly.

an2.43:2.1.eng: And what is a harmonious assembly?

an2.43:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharanti.
an2.43:2.2.eng: An assembly where the mendicants live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.

an2.43:2.3.eng: This is called a harmonious assembly.

an2.43:2.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ samaggā parisā”ti.
an2.43:2.5.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the harmonious assembly.”

an2.44:1.3.pli: Anaggavatī ca parisā aggavatī ca parisā.
an2.44:1.3.eng: An assembly of the worst and an assembly of the best.

an2.44:1.4.eng: And what is an assembly of the worst?

an2.44:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ therā bhikkhū bāhulikā honti sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā, na vīriyaṃ ārabhanti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an2.44:1.5.eng: An assembly where the senior mendicants are indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an2.44:1.6.eng: Those who come after follow their example.

an2.44:1.7.pli: Sāpi hoti bāhulikā sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā, na vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an2.44:1.7.eng: They too become indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, not rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an2.44:1.8.eng: This is called an assembly of the worst.

an2.44:2.1.eng: And what is an assembly of the best?

an2.44:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ therā bhikkhū na bāhulikā honti na sāthalikā, okkamane nikkhittadhurā, paviveke pubbaṅgamā, vīriyaṃ ārabhanti appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an2.44:2.2.eng: An assembly where the senior mendicants are not indulgent or slack, nor are they backsliders; instead, they take the lead in seclusion, rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an2.44:2.3.eng: Those who come after follow their example.

an2.44:2.4.pli: Sāpi hoti na bāhulikā na sāthalikā, okkamane nikkhittadhurā, paviveke pubbaṅgamā, vīriyaṃ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an2.44:2.4.eng: They too are not indulgent or slack, nor are they backsliders; instead, they take the lead in seclusion, rousing energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an2.44:2.5.eng: This is called an assembly of the best.

an2.44:2.7.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ aggavatī parisā”ti.
an2.44:2.7.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the assembly of the best.”

an2.45:1.3.pli: Anariyā ca parisā ariyā ca parisā.
an2.45:1.3.eng: An ignoble assembly and a noble assembly.

an2.45:1.4.eng: And what is an ignoble assembly?

an2.45:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
an2.45:1.5.eng: An assembly where the mendicants don’t truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an2.45:1.6.eng: This is called an ignoble assembly.

an2.45:2.1.eng: And what is a noble assembly?

an2.45:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti.
an2.45:2.2.eng: An assembly where the mendicants truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an2.45:2.3.eng: This is called a noble assembly.

an2.45:2.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ ariyā parisā”ti.
an2.45:2.5.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the noble assembly.”

an2.46:1.3.eng: An assembly of the dregs and an assembly of the cream.

an2.46:1.4.eng: And what is an assembly of the dregs?

an2.46:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū chandāgatiṃ gacchanti, dosāgatiṃ gacchanti, mohāgatiṃ gacchanti, bhayāgatiṃ gacchanti.
an2.46:1.5.eng: An assembly where the mendicants make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

an2.46:1.6.eng: This is called an assembly of the dregs.

an2.46:2.1.eng: And what is an assembly of the cream?

an2.46:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū na chandāgatiṃ gacchanti, na dosāgatiṃ gacchanti, na mohāgatiṃ gacchanti, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchanti.
an2.46:2.2.eng: An assembly where the mendicants make decisions unprejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

an2.46:2.3.eng: This is called an assembly of the cream.

an2.46:2.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ parisāmaṇḍo”ti.
an2.46:2.5.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the assembly of the cream.”

an2.47:1.3.pli: Okkācitavinītā parisā nopaṭipucchāvinītā, paṭipucchāvinītā parisā nookkācitavinītā.
an2.47:1.3.eng: An assembly educated in fancy talk, not in questioning, and an assembly educated in questioning, not in fancy talk.

an2.47:1.4.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, okkācitavinītā parisā nopaṭipucchāvinītā?
an2.47:1.4.eng: And what is an assembly educated in fancy talk, not in questioning?

an2.47:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū ye te suttantā tathāgatabhāsitā gambhīrā gambhīratthā lokuttarā suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttā tesu bhaññamānesu na sussūsanti na sotaṃ odahanti na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti na ca te dhamme uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ maññanti.
an2.47:1.5.eng: It is an assembly where, when discourses spoken by the Realized One—deep, profound, transcendent, dealing with emptiness—are being recited the mendicants do not want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand, nor do they think those teachings are worth learning and memorizing.

an2.47:1.6.pli: Ye pana te suttantā kavitā kāveyyā cittakkharā cittabyañjanā bāhirakā sāvakabhāsitā tesu bhaññamānesu sussūsanti sotaṃ odahanti aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, te dhamme uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ maññanti, te ca taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā na ceva aññamaññaṃ paṭipucchanti na ca paṭivicaranti:
an2.47:1.6.eng: But when discourses composed by poets—poetry, with fancy words and phrases, composed by outsiders or spoken by disciples—are being recited the mendicants do want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand, and they think those teachings are worth learning and memorizing. But when they’ve memorized those teachings they don’t question or examine each other, saying:

an2.47:1.7.eng: ‘Why does it say this? What does that mean?’

an2.47:1.8.pli: Te avivaṭañceva na vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca na uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṃ na paṭivinodenti.
an2.47:1.8.eng: So they don’t reveal what is hidden or clarify what is unclear, or dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.

an2.47:1.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, okkācitavinītā parisā no paṭipucchāvinītā.
an2.47:1.9.eng: This is called an assembly educated in fancy talk, not in questioning.

an2.47:2.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, paṭipucchāvinītā parisā nookkācitavinītā?
an2.47:2.1.eng: And what is an assembly educated in questioning, not in fancy talk?

an2.47:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū ye te suttantā kavitā kāveyyā cittakkharā cittabyañjanā bāhirakā sāvakabhāsitā tesu bhaññamānesu na sussūsanti na sotaṃ odahanti na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca te dhamme uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ maññanti.
an2.47:2.2.eng: It is an assembly where, when discourses composed by poets—poetry, with fancy words and phrases, composed by outsiders or spoken by disciples—are being recited the mendicants do not want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand, nor do they think those teachings are worth learning and memorizing.

an2.47:2.3.pli: Ye pana te suttantā tathāgatabhāsitā gambhīrā gambhīratthā lokuttarā suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttā tesu bhaññamānesu sussūsanti sotaṃ odahanti aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, te ca dhamme uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ maññanti.
an2.47:2.3.eng: But when discourses spoken by the Realized One—deep, profound, transcendent, dealing with emptiness—are being recited the mendicants do want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand, and they think those teachings are worth learning and memorizing.

an2.47:2.4.pli: Te taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā aññamaññaṃ paṭipucchanti paṭivicaranti:
an2.47:2.4.eng: And when they’ve memorized those teachings they question and examine each other, saying:

an2.47:2.5.eng: ‘Why does it say this? What does that mean?’

an2.47:2.6.pli: Te avivaṭañceva vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṃ paṭivinodenti.
an2.47:2.6.eng: So they reveal what is hidden, clarify what is unclear, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.

an2.47:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, paṭipucchāvinītā parisā nookkācitavinītā.
an2.47:2.7.eng: This is called an assembly educated in questioning, not in fancy talk.

an2.47:2.9.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ paṭipucchāvinītā parisā nookkācitavinītā”ti.
an2.47:2.9.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the assembly educated in questioning, not in fancy talk.”

an2.48:1.3.pli: Āmisagaru parisā no saddhammagaru, saddhammagaru parisā no āmisagaru.
an2.48:1.3.eng: An assembly that values things of the flesh, not the true teaching, and an assembly that values the true teaching, not things of the flesh.

an2.48:1.4.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, āmisagaru parisā no saddhammagaru?
an2.48:1.4.eng: And what is an assembly that values things of the flesh, not the true teaching?

an2.48:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū gihīnaṃ odātavasanānaṃ sammukhā aññamaññassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti:
an2.48:1.5.eng: It is an assembly where the mendicants praise each other in front of the white-clothed laypeople, saying:

an2.48:1.6.pli: ‘asuko bhikkhu ubhatobhāgavimutto, asuko paññāvimutto, asuko kāyasakkhī, asuko diṭṭhippatto, asuko saddhāvimutto, asuko dhammānusārī, asuko saddhānusārī, asuko sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo, asuko dussīlo pāpadhammo’ti.
an2.48:1.6.eng: ‘The mendicant so-and-so is freed both ways; so-and-so is freed by wisdom; so-and-so is a direct witness; so-and-so is attained to view; so-and-so is freed by faith; so-and-so is a follower of teachings; so-and-so is a follower by faith; so-and-so is ethical, of good character; so-and-so is unethical, of bad character.’

an2.48:1.8.pli: Te taṃ lābhaṃ labhitvā gathitā mucchitā ajjhopannā anādīnavadassāvino anissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti.
an2.48:1.8.eng: And when they get these things, they use them tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.

an2.48:1.9.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, āmisagaru parisā no saddhammagaru.
an2.48:1.9.eng: This is called an assembly that values things of the flesh, not the true teaching.

an2.48:2.1.pli: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, saddhammagaru parisā noāmisagaru?
an2.48:2.1.eng: And what is an assembly that values the true teaching, not things of the flesh?

an2.48:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū gihīnaṃ odātavasanānaṃ sammukhā aññamaññassa vaṇṇaṃ na bhāsanti:
an2.48:2.2.eng: It is an assembly where the mendicants don’t praise each other in front of the white-clothed laypeople, saying:

an2.48:2.3.pli: ‘asuko bhikkhu ubhatobhāgavimutto, asuko paññāvimutto, asuko kāyasakkhī, asuko diṭṭhippatto, asuko saddhāvimutto, asuko dhammānusārī, asuko saddhānusārī, asuko sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo, asuko dussīlo pāpadhammo’ti.
an2.48:2.3.eng: ‘The mendicant so-and-so is freed both ways; so-and-so is freed by wisdom; so-and-so is a direct witness; so-and-so is attained to view; so-and-so is freed by faith; so-and-so is a follower of teachings; so-and-so is a follower by faith; so-and-so is ethical, of good character; so-and-so is unethical, of bad character.’

an2.48:2.5.pli: Te taṃ lābhaṃ labhitvā agathitā amucchitā anajjhosannā ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti.
an2.48:2.5.eng: And when they get these things, they use them untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.

an2.48:2.6.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, saddhammagaru parisā noāmisagaru.
an2.48:2.6.eng: This is called an assembly that values the true teaching, not things of the flesh.

an2.48:2.8.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ saddhammagaru parisā noāmisagarū”ti.
an2.48:2.8.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the assembly that values the true teaching, not things of the flesh.”

an2.49:1.3.pli: Visamā ca parisā samā ca parisā.
an2.49:1.3.eng: An unjust assembly and a just assembly.

an2.49:1.4.eng: And what is an unjust assembly?

an2.49:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ adhammakammāni pavattanti dhammakammāni nappavattanti, avinayakammāni pavattanti vinayakammāni nappavattanti, adhammakammāni dippanti dhammakammāni na dippanti, avinayakammāni dippanti vinayakammāni na dippanti.
an2.49:1.5.eng: An assembly where legal acts against the teaching proceed, while legal acts following the teaching don’t proceed. Legal acts against the training proceed, while legal acts following the training don’t proceed. Legal acts against the teaching are explained, while legal acts following the teaching aren’t explained. Legal acts against the training are explained, while legal acts following the training aren’t explained.

an2.49:1.6.eng: This is called an unjust assembly.

an2.49:2.1.eng: And what is a just assembly?

an2.49:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ dhammakammāni pavattanti adhammakammāni nappavattanti, vinayakammāni pavattanti avinayakammāni nappavattanti, dhammakammāni dippanti adhammakammāni na dippanti, vinayakammāni dippanti avinayakammāni na dippanti.
an2.49:2.2.eng: An assembly where legal acts following the teaching proceed, while legal acts against the teaching don’t proceed. Legal acts following the training proceed, while legal acts against the training don’t proceed. Legal acts following the teaching are explained, while legal acts against the teaching aren’t explained. Legal acts in line with the training are explained, while legal acts following training aren’t explained.

an2.49:2.3.eng: This is called a just assembly.

an2.49:2.5.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ samā parisā”ti.
an2.49:2.5.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the just assembly.”

an2.50:1.3.pli: Adhammikā ca parisā dhammikā ca parisā …pe… imā kho, bhikkhave, dve parisā.
an2.50:1.3.eng: An unprincipled assembly and a principled assembly …

an2.50:1.4.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammikā parisā”ti.
an2.50:1.4.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the principled assembly.”

an2.51:1.3.pli: Adhammavādinī ca parisā dhammavādinī ca parisā.
an2.51:1.3.eng: An assembly with unprincipled speech, and an assembly with principled speech.

an2.51:1.4.eng: And what is an assembly with unprincipled speech?

an2.51:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū adhikaraṇaṃ ādiyanti dhammikaṃ vā adhammikaṃ vā.
an2.51:1.5.eng: It is an assembly where the mendicants take up disciplinary issues, whether legitimate or not.

an2.51:1.6.pli: Te taṃ adhikaraṇaṃ ādiyitvā na ceva aññamaññaṃ saññāpenti na ca saññattiṃ upagacchanti, na ca nijjhāpenti na ca nijjhattiṃ upagacchanti.
an2.51:1.6.eng: But they don’t persuade each other or allow themselves to be persuaded, nor do they convince each other or allow themselves to be convinced.

an2.51:1.7.pli: Te asaññattibalā anijjhattibalā appaṭinissaggamantino tameva adhikaraṇaṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharanti:
an2.51:1.7.eng: Unable to persuade or convince each other, they can’t let go of their opinions. They obstinately stick to that disciplinary issue, insisting that:

an2.51:1.8.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

an2.51:1.9.eng: This is called an assembly with unprincipled speech.

an2.51:2.1.eng: And what is an assembly with principled speech?

an2.51:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yassaṃ parisāyaṃ bhikkhū adhikaraṇaṃ ādiyanti dhammikaṃ vā adhammikaṃ vā.
an2.51:2.2.eng: It is an assembly where the mendicants take up disciplinary issues, whether legitimate or not.

an2.51:2.3.pli: Te taṃ adhikaraṇaṃ ādiyitvā aññamaññaṃ saññāpenti ceva saññattiñca upagacchanti, nijjhāpenti ceva nijjhattiñca upagacchanti.
an2.51:2.3.eng: Then they persuade each other or allow themselves to be persuaded, and they convince each other or allow themselves to be convinced.

an2.51:2.4.pli: Te saññattibalā nijjhattibalā paṭinissaggamantino, na tameva adhikaraṇaṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharanti:
an2.51:2.4.eng: Since they are able to persuade and convince each other, they let go of their opinions. They don’t obstinately stick to that disciplinary issue or insist that:

an2.51:2.5.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

an2.51:2.6.eng: This is called an assembly with principled speech.

an2.51:2.8.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ parisānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammavādinī parisā”ti.
an2.51:2.8.eng: The better of these two assemblies is the assembly with principled speech.”

an2.52:1.1.pli: “Dveme, bhikkhave, puggalā loke uppajjamānā uppajjanti bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya, bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an2.52:1.1.eng: “These two individuals, mendicants, arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an2.52:1.3.pli: Tathāgato ca arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, rājā ca cakkavattī.
an2.52:1.3.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.

an2.52:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve puggalā loke uppajjamānā uppajjanti bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya, bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
an2.52:1.4.eng: These are the two individuals who arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

an2.53:1.1.pli: “Dveme, bhikkhave, puggalā loke uppajjamānā uppajjanti acchariyamanussā.
an2.53:1.1.eng: “These two individuals, mendicants, arise in the world who are incredible human beings.

an2.53:1.3.pli: Tathāgato ca arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, rājā ca cakkavattī.
an2.53:1.3.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.

an2.53:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve puggalā loke uppajjamānā uppajjanti acchariyamanussā”ti.
an2.53:1.4.eng: These are the two individuals who arise in the world who are incredible human beings.”

an2.54:1.1.pli: “Dvinnaṃ, bhikkhave, puggalānaṃ kālakiriyā bahuno janassa anutappā hoti.
an2.54:1.1.eng: “There are two individuals, mendicants, whose death is regretted by many people.

an2.54:1.3.pli: Tathāgatassa ca arahato sammāsambuddhassa, rañño ca cakkavattissa.
an2.54:1.3.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.

an2.54:1.4.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ puggalānaṃ kālakiriyā bahuno janassa anutappā hotī”ti.
an2.54:1.4.eng: These are the two individuals, mendicants, whose death is regretted by many people.”

an2.55:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these two are worthy of a monument.

an2.55:1.3.pli: Tathāgato ca arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, rājā ca cakkavattī.
an2.55:1.3.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.

an2.55:1.4.eng: These are the two who are worthy of a monument.”

an2.56:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are two kinds of Buddhas.

an2.56:1.3.pli: Tathāgato ca arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, paccekabuddho ca.
an2.56:1.3.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and an Independent Buddha.

an2.56:1.4.eng: These are the two kinds of Buddhas.”

an2.57:1.1.eng: “These two, mendicants, are not startled by a crack of thunder.

an2.57:1.3.eng: A mendicant who has ended defilements; and a thoroughbred elephant.

an2.57:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve asaniyā phalantiyā na santasantī”ti.
an2.57:1.4.eng: These are the two who are not startled by a crack of thunder.”

an2.58:1.1.eng: “These two, mendicants, are not startled by a crack of thunder.

an2.58:1.3.eng: A mendicant who has ended defilements; and a thoroughbred horse.

an2.58:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve asaniyā phalantiyā na santasantī”ti.
an2.58:1.4.eng: These are the two who are not startled by a crack of thunder.”

an2.59:1.1.eng: “These two, mendicants, are not startled by a crack of thunder.

an2.59:1.3.pli: Bhikkhu ca khīṇāsavo, sīho ca migarājā.
an2.59:1.3.eng: A mendicant who has ended defilements; and a lion, king of beasts.

an2.59:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve asaniyā phalantiyā na santasantī”ti.
an2.59:1.4.eng: These are the two who are not startled by a crack of thunder.”

an2.60:1.1.pli: “Dveme, bhikkhave, atthavase sampassamānā kiṃpurisā mānusiṃ vācaṃ na bhāsanti.
an2.60:1.1.eng: “Aborigines see two reasons not to use regular speech.

an2.60:1.3.pli: Mā ca musā bhaṇimhā, mā ca paraṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhimhāti.
an2.60:1.3.eng: Thinking: ‘May we not lie, and may we not misrepresent others with falsehoods.’

an2.60:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, dve atthavase sampassamānā kiṃpurisā mānusiṃ vācaṃ na bhāsantī”ti.
an2.60:1.4.eng: Aborigines see these two reasons not to use regular speech.”

an2.61:1.1.pli: “Dvinnaṃ dhammānaṃ, bhikkhave, atitto appaṭivāno mātugāmo kālaṃ karoti.
an2.61:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, ladies die without getting enough of two things.

an2.61:1.4.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ dhammānaṃ atitto appaṭivāno mātugāmo kālaṃ karotī”ti.
an2.61:1.4.eng: Females die without getting enough of these two things.”

an2.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you about living with bad people and living with good people.

an2.62:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an2.62:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an2.62:1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an2.62:2.1.pli: “Kathañca, bhikkhave, asantasannivāso hoti, kathañca asanto sannivasanti?
an2.62:2.1.eng: “What is it like living with bad people? How do bad people live together?

an2.62:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, therassa bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti:
an2.62:2.2.eng: It’s when a senior mendicant thinks:

an2.62:2.3.pli: ‘theropi maṃ na vadeyya, majjhimopi maṃ na vadeyya, navopi maṃ na vadeyya;
an2.62:2.3.eng: ‘No mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, should admonish me;

an2.62:2.4.pli: therampāhaṃ na vadeyyaṃ, majjhimampāhaṃ na vadeyyaṃ, navampāhaṃ na vadeyyaṃ.
an2.62:2.4.eng: and I shouldn’t admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.

an2.62:2.5.pli: Thero cepi maṃ vadeyya ahitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no hitānukampī, noti naṃ vadeyyaṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa nappaṭikareyyaṃ.
an2.62:2.5.eng: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they wouldn’t be sympathetic, and I’d bother them by saying “No!” And anyway I wouldn’t deal with it even if I saw what I did wrong.’

an2.62:2.6.pli: Majjhimo cepi maṃ vadeyya …pe… navo cepi maṃ vadeyya, ahitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no hitānukampī, noti naṃ vadeyyaṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa nappaṭikareyyaṃ’.

an2.62:2.7.pli: Majjhimassapi bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti …pe… navassapi bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti:
an2.62:2.7.eng: And a middle or a junior mendicant also thinks:

an2.62:2.8.pli: ‘theropi maṃ na vadeyya, majjhimopi maṃ na vadeyya, navopi maṃ na vadeyya;
an2.62:2.8.eng: ‘No mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, should admonish me;

an2.62:2.9.pli: therampāhaṃ na vadeyyaṃ, majjhimampāhaṃ na vadeyyaṃ, navampāhaṃ na vadeyyaṃ.
an2.62:2.9.eng: and I shouldn’t admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.

an2.62:2.10.pli: Thero cepi maṃ vadeyya ahitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no hitānukampī noti naṃ vadeyyaṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa nappaṭikareyyaṃ.
an2.62:2.10.eng: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they wouldn’t be sympathetic, and I’d bother them by saying “No!” And anyway I wouldn’t deal with it even if I saw what I did wrong.’

an2.62:2.11.pli: Majjhimo cepi maṃ vadeyya … navo cepi maṃ vadeyya ahitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no hitānukampī, noti naṃ vadeyyaṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa nappaṭikareyyaṃ’.

an2.62:2.12.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asantasannivāso hoti, evañca asanto sannivasanti.
an2.62:2.12.eng: That’s what it’s like living with bad people; that’s how bad people live together.

an2.62:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, santasannivāso hoti, kathañca santo sannivasanti?
an2.62:3.1.eng: What is it like living with good people? How do good people live together?

an2.62:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, therassa bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti:
an2.62:3.2.eng: It’s when a senior mendicant thinks:

an2.62:3.3.pli: ‘theropi maṃ vadeyya, majjhimopi maṃ vadeyya, navopi maṃ vadeyya;
an2.62:3.3.eng: ‘Any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, should admonish me;

an2.62:3.4.pli: therampāhaṃ vadeyyaṃ, majjhimampāhaṃ vadeyyaṃ, navampāhaṃ vadeyyaṃ.
an2.62:3.4.eng: and I should admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.

an2.62:3.5.pli: Thero cepi maṃ vadeyya hitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no ahitānukampī, sādhūti naṃ vadeyyaṃ na naṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa paṭikareyyaṃ.
an2.62:3.5.eng: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they’d be sympathetic, so I wouldn’t bother them, but say “Thank you!” And I’d deal with it when I saw what I did wrong.’

an2.62:3.6.pli: Majjhimo cepi maṃ vadeyya …pe… navo cepi maṃ vadeyya hitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no ahitānukampī, sādhūti naṃ vadeyyaṃ na naṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa paṭikareyyaṃ’.

an2.62:3.7.pli: Majjhimassapi bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti …pe… navassapi bhikkhuno evaṃ hoti:
an2.62:3.7.eng: And a middle or a junior mendicant also thinks:

an2.62:3.8.pli: ‘theropi maṃ vadeyya, majjhimopi maṃ vadeyya, navopi maṃ vadeyya;
an2.62:3.8.eng: ‘Any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, may admonish me;

an2.62:3.9.pli: therampāhaṃ vadeyyaṃ, majjhimampāhaṃ vadeyyaṃ, navampāhaṃ vadeyyaṃ.
an2.62:3.9.eng: and I’ll admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.

an2.62:3.10.pli: Thero cepi maṃ vadeyya hitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no ahitānukampī, sādhūti naṃ vadeyyaṃ na naṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa paṭikareyyaṃ.
an2.62:3.10.eng: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they’d be sympathetic, so I wouldn’t bother them, but say “Thank you!” And I’d deal with it when I saw what I did wrong.’

an2.62:3.11.pli: Majjhimo cepi maṃ vadeyya …pe… navo cepi maṃ vadeyya hitānukampī maṃ vadeyya no ahitānukampī, sādhūti naṃ vadeyyaṃ na naṃ viheṭheyyaṃ passampissa paṭikareyyaṃ’.

an2.62:3.12.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, santasannivāso hoti, evañca santo sannivasantī”ti.
an2.62:3.12.eng: That’s what it’s like living with good people; that’s how good people live together.”

an2.63:1.1.pli: “Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, adhikaraṇe ubhato vacīsaṃsāro diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi ajjhattaṃ avūpasantaṃ hoti, tasmetaṃ, bhikkhave, adhikaraṇe pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
an2.63:1.1.eng: “In any disciplinary issue where on both sides the endless talk, contempt for each other’s views, resentment, bitterness, and exasperation is not settled, you can expect that this disciplinary issue

an2.63:1.2.pli: ‘dīghattāya kharattāya vāḷattāya saṃvattissati, bhikkhū ca na phāsuṃ viharissanti’.
an2.63:1.2.eng: will lead to lasting acrimony and enmity, and the mendicants will not live comfortably.

an2.63:2.1.pli: Yasmiñca kho, bhikkhave, adhikaraṇe ubhato vacīsaṃsāro diṭṭhipaḷāso cetaso āghāto appaccayo anabhiraddhi ajjhattaṃ suvūpasantaṃ hoti, tasmetaṃ, bhikkhave, adhikaraṇe pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
an2.63:2.1.eng: In any disciplinary issue where on both sides the endless talk, contempt for each other’s views, resentment, bitterness, and exasperation is well settled, you can expect that this disciplinary issue

an2.63:2.2.pli: ‘na dīghattāya kharattāya vāḷattāya saṃvattissati, bhikkhū ca phāsuṃ viharissantī’”ti.
an2.63:2.2.eng: won’t lead to lasting acrimony and enmity, and the mendicants will live comfortably.”
